content.raw:
We should be able to split the special release type from the version argument:

`ign_configure_project(common 0.5.0 pre)`

The `pre` would fall into the `${ARGV}` of `ign_configure_project(~)`.

From this, we could construct the "full version" type as `0.5.0~pre`. We may also need to consider doing something like [this](https://github.com/google/protobuf/pull/1624) in order for cmake users to correctly find special release versions using `find_package(~)`.

Edit: Alternatively, if we can come up with a fixed list of special release types that we are willing to support, we could have them as optional arguments: `ign_configure_project(common 0.5.0 PRE)` where `PRE` (or `ALPHA` or `BETA`) are predetermined optional arguments which tell `ignition-cmake` to configure the project as the special release type. This would be forwards-compatible with any potential changes we might want to make to `ign_configure_project(~)` in the future.
content.html:
We should be able to split the special release type from the version argument:

ign_configure_project(common 0.5.0 pre)

The pre would fall into the ${ARGV} of ign_configure_project(~).

From this, we could construct the "full version" type as 0.5.0~pre. We may also need to consider doing something like this in order for cmake users to correctly find special release versions using find_package(~).

Edit: Alternatively, if we can come up with a fixed list of special release types that we are willing to support, we could have them as optional arguments: ign_configure_project(common 0.5.0 PRE) where PRE (or ALPHA or BETA) are predetermined optional arguments which tell ignition-cmake to configure the project as the special release type. This would be forwards-compatible with any potential changes we might want to make to ign_configure_project(~) in the future.

content.raw: Thanks Michael. Fully agree with the ideas. Having the ability to define all kind of custom suffixes would be good but I tried to keep our upstream versions sane and don't use much more than alpha, beta and prerelease. Both options works for me at this moment.
content.html: Thanks Michael. Fully agree with the ideas. Having the ability to define all kind of custom suffixes would be good but I tried to keep our upstream versions sane and don't use much more than alpha, beta and prerelease. Both options works for me at this moment.

content.raw:
I just made the next prerelease of ignition-cmake with version 0.1.1:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/commits/835c374fc1cd53846b0c8855e2b9c2ddc6d4f7c9?at=ignition-cmake_0.1.1

I wasn't able to use the `~pre1` suffix like was used in ignition-math4 prior to merging ignition-cmake support:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/e48d6fc0ba840e9e391790f9a04f1a272667112c?at=ignition-math4_4.0.0%7Epre1

This functionality would be kinda helpful for making prereleases so we can distinguish the prerelease tags from real tags.
content.html:
I just made the next prerelease of ignition-cmake with version 0.1.1:

This functionality would be kinda helpful for making prereleases so we can distinguish the prerelease tags from real tags.

content.raw: I think I like the idea of a `VERSION_SUFFIX` keyword that takes a string like `~pre1` and appends that to the version string.
content.html: I think I like the idea of a VERSION_SUFFIX keyword that takes a string like ~pre1 and appends that to the version string.

content.raw: Do you think the tilde should be part of the input argument, or should we infer/enforce that a tilde is used between the version number and the prerelease suffix?
content.html: Do you think the tilde should be part of the input argument, or should we infer/enforce that a tilde is used between the version number and the prerelease suffix?

content.raw:
One question to address: Do we want to allow users to be able to specifically ask for the prerelease version of a package? In other words, suppose a user has both `ign-math4.2.0` and `ign-math4.2.0~prerelease` installed. The `find_package` function does not allow users to specifically request a prerelease, so when they call `find_package(ignition-math4 4.2.0)`, it's ambiguous whether they want to find `4.2.0` or `4.2.0~prerelease`.

Protobuf has a workaround [which you can see here](https://github.com/google/protobuf/pull/1624). We could also take this approach, but it would require us to maintain our own version compatibility file instead of allowing CMake to autogenerate it.

Alternatively, we could potentially ignore all of these concerns and just allow the suffix to be superficial from the point of view of cmake.

If this is something that has already been worked out previously in some ignition projects, then I'll gladly copy the behavior from those.
content.html:
One question to address: Do we want to allow users to be able to specifically ask for the prerelease version of a package? In other words, suppose a user has both ign-math4.2.0 and ign-math4.2.0~prerelease installed. The find_package function does not allow users to specifically request a prerelease, so when they call find_package(ignition-math4 4.2.0), it's ambiguous whether they want to find 4.2.0 or 4.2.0~prerelease.

Protobuf has a workaround which you can see here. We could also take this approach, but it would require us to maintain our own version compatibility file instead of allowing CMake to autogenerate it.

Alternatively, we could potentially ignore all of these concerns and just allow the suffix to be superficial from the point of view of cmake.

If this is something that has already been worked out previously in some ignition projects, then I'll gladly copy the behavior from those.

content.raw:
With respect to the enforce of the `~` , I think that it is a decision from our side as upstream to mark the version suffixes of our software.

Note that upstream versions (versions in source code) and downstream versions (Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, ...) can be different. The use of the `~` makes Ubuntu/Debian downstream easier so it is not a bad idea to use instead of just append the suffix without a separator or use a different symbol.  I've been using other symbols, concretely the character +, in downstream versions (to mark snapshots of code +date+commit or use the suffix +osrf) but I think that they have no sense in upstream.

Speaking about how cmake perceive the ~prereleases, ~alpha or ~beta, I think that is is ok to ignore them since most of the times we want third party software to threat them as if they supply the 'stable' version with testing proposes. I only see corner cases in which we want to distinguish between prereleases and stable versions and again, it could be solve at a package level with downstream packaging techniques.
content.html:
With respect to the enforce of the ~ , I think that it is a decision from our side as upstream to mark the version suffixes of our software.

Note that upstream versions (versions in source code) and downstream versions (Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, ...) can be different. The use of the ~ makes Ubuntu/Debian downstream easier so it is not a bad idea to use instead of just append the suffix without a separator or use a different symbol. I've been using other symbols, concretely the character +, in downstream versions (to mark snapshots of code +date+commit or use the suffix +osrf) but I think that they have no sense in upstream.

Speaking about how cmake perceive the ~prereleases, ~alpha or ~beta, I think that is is ok to ignore them since most of the times we want third party software to threat them as if they supply the 'stable' version with testing proposes. I only see corner cases in which we want to distinguish between prereleases and stable versions and again, it could be solve at a package level with downstream packaging techniques.
